dialogues.speaker: FADE IN
dialogues.text: OVER the opening strains of "I LOVE YOU, CALIFORNIA," a MONTAGE:  a mixture of headlines, newsreel footage and live action.  Economy Booming!  Postwar Optimism!  L.A.: City of the Future!  But most prominent among them: GANGLAND!  Police photographers document crime scenes. The meat wagon hauls ex-button men to the morgue.  Where will it end?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Palm trees in silhouette against a cherry sky.  City lights twinkle.  Los Angeles.  A place where anything is possible.  A place where dreams come true.  As the sky darkens, triple-kleig lights begin to sweep back and forth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The KLEIG LIGHTS are out front.  Valets hurry to park a line of elegant cars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ladies and gentlemen, I give you the future of Los Angeles!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The MAYOR yanks a cloth to reveal a MODEL of L.A. criss- crossed by an elaborate FREEWAY SYSTEM.  The CROWD oohs. A COUNCILMAN claps.  A SOCIETY MATRON nods her approval. PIERCE PATCHETT, 50, tuxedoed, watches off to one side. A behind-the-scenes power broker, Patchett exudes authority much more so than the Mayor does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Arroyo Seco freeway is just the beginning.  We're planning freeways from Downtown to Santa Monica, from the South Bay to the San Fernando Valley.  Twenty minutes to work or play is the longest you'll have to travel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More applause.  One REPORTER asks a little too loudly...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many bodies you think Mickey Cohen'll be able to hide in all that cement?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Mayor wears a plastic smile, ignores it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CLUB PHOTOGRAPHER pops snapshots, but the real action is on the floor where MICKEY COHEN does a wicked "Lindy Hop" with THREE different GIRLS at once.  A fireplug of a man, he hardly seems a public menace.  Nearby is his bodyguard JOHNNY STOMPANATO.  Over it all:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meyer Harris Cohen, Mickey C to his fans.  He's the big moocher, local L.A. color to the nth degree.  You know Mickey.  He runs dope, rackets and prostitution. He kills a dozen people a year. But who you may not know is bodyguard Johnny Stompanato.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His hair in a slick pompadour, Stompanato keeps an eye on Cohen and comes onto a CIGARETTE GIRL at the same time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnny's handsome, ladies, but the real attraction is below the belt. Second only to Steve Cochran, he's sometimes known as 'Oscar' because of his Academy Award-size appendage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mickey works a sweat on the dance floor.  A bottle of champagne pops; Stompanato reacts, nearly draws a pistol from his shoulder holster.  As he laughs at himself...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lurid page one headlines cover the wall where SID HUDGEONS types.  The essence of sleaze, Sid is the publisher-photographer-writer of Hush-Hush magazine and keeper of inside dirt supreme.  As he continues...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember, dear readers, you heard it here first, off the record, on the Q.T. and very Hush-Hush.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The party continues.  The Mayor has moved off to the side with the power brokers.  Patchett is a presence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're selling an image, gentlemen. Beautiful weather.  Affordable housing. (re:  model) Trouble-free transportation.  And the best police department in the world to keep it all running smoothly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dozen people watch a display windoe TELEVISION as it rolls the opening of the hit show "Badge of Honor."  Over familiar THEME MUSIC, "Sgt. Joe Reno" (actor BRETT CHASE) walks the streets of Los Angeles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name?  Joe Reno.  The city? Los Angeles.  A big town.  Full of all sorts of people.  It's my job to help them.  I like what I do. I'm a cop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Mayor continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But with a second rate Al Capone out there, L.A. looks like Chicago in the '30s.  Something has to be done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Pierce Patchett nods sagely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wrestler GORGEOUS GEORGE primps and poses before flatten- ing an opponent with a drop kick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An enthusiastic crowd adjusts their 3-D glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In monogrammed silk pajamas, Mickey Cohen answers the door, his pet BULLDOG Mickey Jr. at his feet.  The police are waiting.  REPORTERS' flashbulbs pop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Cohen, you're under arrest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bullshit.  What's the charge?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Non-payment of federal income tax.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bullshit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOHN WAYNE gets his hand prints in the sidewalk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MIGRANT WORKERS hurry to finish the harvest.  We PAN TO CONSTRUCTION WORKERS who wait impatiently with bull- dozers under a "Spirit of the Future" BANNER.  As the last picker leaves the field, the bulldozers move in, leveling the bean rows to make way for a housing tract.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flashbulbs pop as Mickey Cohen exits and starts down the steps.  Accompanied by his LAWYERS, bodyguard Stompanato and mob lieutenants DEUCE PERKINS and NATE JANKLOW, Cohen ignores REPORTERS' shouts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's your bullshit now, Mickey?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Cohen gets into a waiting car, the media turn their attention to District Attorney ELLIS LOEW.  A singularly ambitious man, Loew loves the spotlight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Today is an auspicious one for the city of Los Angeles.  Mickey Cohen has just been sentenced to ten years in federal prison for failure to pay income tax. As the District Attorney for Los Angeles County, it is my pleasure to declare our great city organized crime free.  It is truly the dawning of a new day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SONG ENDS and so does the MONTAGE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: December 24th.  Wendell "BUD" WHITE, 30, stares at the enormous Christmas tree on the deco platform over Bullocks' entrance.  An LAPD cop, Bud's rep as the toughest man on the force has been well earned.  In the back seat, with cases of Walker Black and Cutty Sark, is Bud's partner -- DICK STENSLAND.  Older, but also a tough hump, "Stens" sucks on a pint of Old Crow. The passenger door opens and Mickey Cohen bodyguard Johnny Stompanato slides in.  Guinea handsome, Johnny wears his curls in a tight pompadour.  With his boss behind bars, he's out of work.  Bud just stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Officer White.  I heard you got a hard-on for wife beaters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you fuck people up for a living.  That don't make me you. Capisce, shitbird?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stompanato smiles.  Nervous.  Through the window, Bud watches a Salvation Army Santa palm coins from a kettle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud ain't in the mood for small talk, Stompanato.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Mickey C's doing time and half the other guys who'd hire me are dead or left town.  I need money.  If your snitch-fund's green, I'll get you some fucking-A collars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Impatient, Bud tugs at a finger, CRACKS a KNUCKLE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's this guy.  He's blond and fat, about forty.  Likes the ponies.  Been pimping his wife to cover his losses.  Knocks her around to keep her in line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud's eyes narrow at this last bit of info.  Stompanato holds up a slip of paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I figure the address is worth twenty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud digs into his wallet, pulls out twenty bucks, exchanges it with Stompanato.  Stompanato smiles smugly, grabs a bottle of Scotch from the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yuletide cheer, fellas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Without warning, Bud grabs Stompanato's tie and yanks, slamming his forehead into the dash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Happy New Year, greaseball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A stucco job in a row of vet prefabs.  A neon Santa sleigh has landed on the roof.  Through the front window, we see a fat guy browbeating a woman.  Puff-faced, 35- ish, she backs away as he rages at her. The Packard pulls up out front.  Stensland could care less.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave it for later, Bud.  We got to pick up the rest of the booze and get back to the precinct.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud KILLS the IGNITION, picks up the radio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Central, this is 4A-31.  Send a prowler to 1486 Evergreen.  White male in custody.  Code 623 point one.  Domestic assault and battery.  I won't be here, but they'll see him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: steps to the house.  Inside, we hear SLAPS, MUFFLED CRIES.  Bud grips an outlet cord coming off the roof and yanks.  The sleigh crashes to the ground with REINDEER EXPLODING around it.  A beat.  The fat guy runs out to investigate, trips over Rudolph. Bud pounces.  Fat guy takes a swing, misses.  Grabbing fat guy's hair, Bud smashes his face to the pavement. Once, twice.  Teeth skitter down the walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Touch her again and I'll know about it.  Understand?  Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another face full of gravel.  Fat guy's WIFE watches with apprehension from the steps as Bud cuffs her husband's hands behind his back, empties his pockets.  A cash roll and car keys.  Bud looks over at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got someplace you can go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She nods.  Bud hands her the keys and the cash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go get yourself fixed up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods, determined) Merry Christmas, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud watches as she gets into a pre-war Ford in the drive. She backs over a blinking reindeer as she goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You and women, partner.  What's next?  Kids and dogs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The "Badge of Honor" set.  A Christmas party in full swing.  Eating, drinking, and dancing.  Star Brett Chase, seen earlier on television, is holding court. LAPD Sgt. "Trashcan" JACK VINCENNES, late 30s with slick, good looks, dances with a young ACTRESS.  Grinding their way through a ballad, they're obviously hitting it off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brett Chase told me you're the cop who busted Bob Mitchum. (grinds closer) These 'Badge of Honor' guys like to pretend, but being the real thing must be a thrill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go someplace quiet.  I'll give you the low-down on Mitchum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got your handcuffs with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two sets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll get my coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're interrupted by Sid Hudgeons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big V Jack Vincennes!  May I have this dance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Karen, this is Sid Hudgeons from Hush-Hush magazine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know who he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Actress storms off.  Jack looks to Sid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We did a piece last year. 'Ingenue Dykes In Hollywood.'  Her name got mentioned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beats me.  Look, Jackie-Boy, a friend of mine just sold some reefer to Matt Reynolds.  He's tripping the light fantastic with Tammy Jordan at 2245 Maravilla, Hollywood Hills.  It's right around the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You lost me, Sid.  Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Contract players at Metro.  You pinch 'em.  I do you up feature in the next issue.  Plus the usual fifty cash.  Tell me, am I fucking Santa Claus?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need an extra fifty.  Two patrolmen at twenty apiece and a dime for the watch commander at Hollywood Station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack!  It's Christmas!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  It's felony possession of marijuana.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WITH a VIEW of Grauman's Chinese.  Jack and two uniformed patrolmen wait on the darkened street.  An arc light has been set up.  Hudgeons creeps back over from the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're sitting in the dark, goofing on the Christmas tree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stand there with your camera. I'll stop here so you get Grauman's Chinese in the backgrouns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like it!  I like it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The arc light floods the living room about the same time that Jack kicks the door in.  The room is caught flush: Christmas tree, a bag of weed on the couch, two kids necking in their BVDs.  MATT REYNOLDS and TAMMY JORDAN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Police!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack exits, hauling Jordan and Reynolds by the neck. Jack stops with Grauman's FRAMED behind him and Hudgeons CLICKS off several shots with his CAMERA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cut!  Wrap it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Windows light up.  Rubberneckers appear.  Jack hands the kids to the patrolmen, heads back in with Hudgeons in tow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack scoops the pot, flips through an address book.  A card falls out.  "Fleur-de-Lis.  Whatever you desire..." Jack looks from the card out the window at the kids being loaded into a black and white.  They're both crying now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stantorian tone) It's Christmas morning in the City of Angels, and while decent citizens sleep the sleep of the righteous, hopheads prowl for marijuana, not knowing that a man is coming to stop them.  The free- wheeling, big-time Big V, celebrity crime-stopper, Jack Vincennes, the scourge of grasshoppers and junk fiends everywhere.  You like it, Jackie- Boy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, it's subtle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sid hands him a President Grant 50.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember: you heard it first here, off the record, on the Q.T. and very Hush-Hush.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suspects, mostly drunk and disorderly, are ushered through.  Sgt. ED EXLEY, 30, bespectacled, is at the desk with a YOUNG OFFICER.  Exley is an up-and-comer.  Burning with ambition.  The faster he rises through the ranks, the more resentment he leaves in his wake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's on the call sheet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A guy dressed as Santa has been exposing himself to kids in Los Feliz.  Apparently, sir, he's decorated himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Decorated?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With tinsel and plastic icicles and... on his penis, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I get the idea.  You got a description?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of his penis, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tinsel-trimmed photos of movie stars look down from the walls as the OWNER takes an order from LYNN BRACKEN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A case each of gin, Scotch, and rum.  Everything top shelf.  None of that watered-down stuff you push on Errol Flynn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs) Sounds like a helluva party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her hair kerchiefed, Lynn waits as the Owner writes it up.  There's glamour, a cat-girl grace about Lynn.  She seems like she belongs up on the wall with the movie stars.  Lynn looks across as Bud White heads toward the counter.  Spotting her, Bud doesn't look so tough for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want it delivered?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before five tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Owner spots Bud.  A big smile turns to a frown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be right with you, Lynn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Owner begins indiscriminately loading hard liquor into a cardboard box, leaving Bud and Lynn to look at each other.  Bud says the only thing he can think of.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merry Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merry Christmas yourself, Officer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That obvious, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles sweetly) It's practically stamped on your forehead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the Owner bangs a case of liquor on the counter...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud exits with his booze, heads for the car.  Something catches his eye.  A woman in the rear passenger seat of a new Cadillac.  SUSAN LEFFERTS.  Both her eyes are black. Bud starts over.  The case on his hip, he motions for her to roll down the window.  The driver's side door opens and bodyguard TURNER "BUZZ" MEEKS menaces his way out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get lost why don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meeks stops short as Bud shoves his badge in Meeks' face. Setting the case on the car's hood, Bud spins Meeks around, pats him down.  He finds a .38 in a shoulder holster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got a license for that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud removes Meeks' wallet, checks the ID.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cut me some slack.  I used to be a cop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turner Meeks?  Never heard of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exiting store) We just call him Buzz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud raps on Susan's window with his badge.  It comes down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beside her, a man leans over.  Pierce Patchett, seen before at the freeway unveiling, is a man used to being chauffeured.  Like FDR, he smokes his cigarette in a holder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (menacing) I'm not asking you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patchett has no idea he's walking on thin ice.  As he stares impatiently at Bud, Bud looks back to Susan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody hit you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not what you think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud looks to see Lynn Bracken moving to the driver's door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got the wrong idea, Mister. I'm fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan laughs.  Patchett eases back into the shadows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting in the car) But it's nice to know you care.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud considers Meeks' gun license, then hands him back the .38 and wallet.  Lifting his booze, Bud watches Meeks get back in the car. Stensland steps up as the cabbie starts to pull away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For an odd moment, Stensland and Meeks lock eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seen him around.  He used to be a cop.

dialogues.speaker: DUDLEY SMITH
dialogues.text: Fifty, handsome in his police captain's uniform.  Singing "Silver Bells" in a beautiful low tenor.  Tough, respected, Dudley goes to bed as a cop every night of his life.  He's a department power to be reckoned with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An L.A. Herald Express REPORTER and photographer listen along with the gathered patrolmen as Dudley finishes to applause.  Dudley joins the press.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain Smith, I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drop the formalities; it's Christmas Eve.  Call me Dudley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dudley, I came up with a title for the story.  I'm calling it "Silent Night with the L.A.P.D."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excellent.  How's this? (dramatic pause) The sanctity of the night is an invitation to the darker criminal element.  Our vigilance will not be diminished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the Reporter scribbles down the quote...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's Smith with an S.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They laugh.  Dudley points the way out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This way, gentlemen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dudley's the last one out the door.  As he goes, he turns back to give the men a wink.  He's no sooner out the door when the first case of Johnny Walker is brought in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed Exley gets another report from the Young Officer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two police officers were assaulted in a bar.  Brown and Helenowski.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands the report to Exley.  It's now that Dudley comes through on his press junket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Sergeant Ed Exley.  Son of the legendary Preston Exley.  He's the watch commander tonight and a damn fine job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the photographer snaps Exley's picture...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was fortunate enough to be partnered with his father when I was a rookie.  It makes a man feel old.  That's a fact. (a beat) Feel free to get a feel for the place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the Reporter and photographer wander off, Dudley turns to Exley a bit more serious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A word with you, lad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dudley pours two drinks, hands one to Exley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To the memory of your father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They drink.  Exley looks to a photo on the wall. Himself as a ten-year-old standing between Dudley and his father Preston, both in police uniform.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The day he got the Medal of Valor. A simpler time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remembering, Exley invokes his father's favorite toast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To the solving of crimes that require absolute justice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exley raises his glass, but Dudley just watches him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was his favorite toast. (a beat) I saw the test results on the lieutenant's exam.  You placed first out of twenty-three.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The youngest applicant by eight years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll make lieutenant inside a year.  Patrol division?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was thinking Detective Bureau.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can see Dudley doesn't approve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have the eye for human weakness to be a good detective. Or the stomach.  You're a political animal, Edmund.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The criticism stings, but Dudley's a straight shooter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I...?  Would you be willing to plant corroborative evidence on a suspect you knew was guilty in order to ensure an indictment?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dudley, we've been over this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Answer yes or no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I... No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you be willing to rig crime scene evidence to support a prosecuting attorney's working hypothesis...?  Yes or no, Edmund.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you be willing to beat confessions out of suspects you knew to be guilty?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you be willing to shoot hardened criminals in the back to offset the chance --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then for God's sake, don't be a detective.  Stick to assignments where you won't have to make those choices.  Patrol, Internal Affairs, but not the Bureau.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you mean well, Dudley, but I don't need to do it the way you did.  Or my father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At least get rid of the glasses. I can't think of one Bureau man who wears them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A large impromptu bar has been set-up.  The party is in full swing, the floor packed with nightwatch blues.  A PHONOGRAPH SPEWS DIRTY CHRISTMAS CAROLS. Stensland pours eggnog and Old Crow into the water cooler as Bud elbows his way in with another case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, partner.  Grab a cup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got to write my report first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hear about Helenowski and Brown? They got into a helluva scrap with six taco benders at some bar. Helenowski lost six pints of blood.  Brown's in a coma.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We ought to teach Paco and his friends a lesson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More cops vocie their agreement.  Bottles are passed. Only Bud doesn't seem as caught-up as the rest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack Vincennes at his desk.  Holding the Fleur-de-Lis card, Jack dials the number.  A corkboard on the wall is posted with press clippings.  "Dope Crusader Wounded in Shootout."  "Actor Mitchum Seized in Marijuana Shack Raid."  That one includes a shot of Jack ushering Mitchum into jail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over phone, like silk) Whatever you desire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi... I'd like to get a delivery to Beverly Hills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over phone) I don't think I know you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLICK.  The line goes dead.  Jack redials.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over phone) Whatever you desire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, a friend of mine gave me this number.  I just --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The line goes dead again.  Jack dials a new number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (filtered) Pacific Coast Bell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Sgt. Vincennes. Requesting a name and address on a phone number.  Hollywood zero-one- two-three-nine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (filtered) Please hold the line... No such number is assigned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just called it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Sergeant.  I checked twice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (realizes, hangs up) A bootleg...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exley surveys the carousing rowdies.  Raising his voice...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, men.  You've had your fun.  Time to break it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The party continues undiminished.  From across the room, Stensland eyes Exley with disdain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fucking Exley.  Guy's got a pole so far up his ass, every time he farts the flag waves.

dialogues.speaker: WATCH COMMANDER'S OFFICE
dialogues.text: The command not really his, Exley reads a report, ignores the party, though his window looks into the thick of it. Suddenly a ripple goes through the room.  The men begin to push out through a rear door.  Exley stands, stops a COP.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They got the spics who japped Helenowski and Brown.  Helenowski lost an eye and Brown's got brain damage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have the report right here. They're home with bruises and muscle pulls -- Oh shit...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exley starts out after them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stensland in the lead.  Pulling out a blackjack, he enters Cell #4, begins wailing on one of the Mexicans -- Dinardo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For ours, Pancho. And you're getting off easy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheered on by drunks in the tank and his fellow officers, Stensland goes wild.  He's joined by Lentz, Crumley and Tristano.  Shaking his head, Jack Vincennes moves away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud types his report with one finger.  Jack looks in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: White, you better get a lease on Stens before he kills someone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Followed by Jack, Bud forces his way through the crowd. The men who see it's him quickly clear a path. Swigging from a pint of gin, Stensland works skinny GARCIA.  Head saps.  The kid drops to his knees drooling blood. Bud grabs Stensland, hauls him off of Garcia who looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you, pendejo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah yeah...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And fuck your mother too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud sees red.  Letting go of Stensland, Bud White picks up Garcia by the neck.  There are cheers, "Attaboys" and "Holy Fucks" as Bud bangs Garcia's head on the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (arriving) Stop, Officer!  That's an order!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cops block Exley's way.  As Bud looks over, Garcia kicks him in the balls.  A dangling shot.  Bud keels into the bars, Garcia stumbles out of the cell, smack into Jack. Jack looks down aghast at blood on his cashmere blazer, then puts Garcia down with a left-right. Exley pulls a pad of paper and pen form his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're going in my report!  All of you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exley has just started taking names when Bud grabs him by the scruff of the neck and hauls him off balance into...

dialogues.speaker: HALL
dialogues.text: As Exley struggles, a cop opens the door to the store room.  Bud slings Exley inside, then slams the door tight.  Exley is locked in.  As Bud moves off, we hear POUNDING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me out!  That's an order!

dialogues.speaker: CELL BLOCK
dialogues.text: The Herald Reporter and photographer enter unchaperoned and unnoticed.  Stensland swings like a madman.  That's when a flashbulb goes off.  Freezing everyone in black and white.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CHIEF sits behind a desk in a four-star uniform. Dudley Smith sits to his left, D.A. Ellis Loew to his right.  Seen earlier at the Mickey Cohen press conference, Loew is the only civilian.  Bud White stands across from them.  There to be judged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Officer White, you've refused to cooperate with Internal Affairs. But you should know this is bigger than a police board.  Indictments may be handed down.  Quite frankly, we need police witnesses to offset the damage done to the Department's image.  Will you testify?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud glances to a gray tinted mirror, then to the Chief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, sir.  I won't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Chief sighs, looks to Loew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: District Attorney Loew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loew steps to Bud, holds up a newspaper with the cell block photo.  The headline:  "BLOODY CHRISTMAS."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bloody Christmas.  The press love to label.  You and Officer Stensland brought the liquor into the precinct.  Stensland was already drunk.  Do you see how appearing as a voluntary witness against him could offset the damage you've done to yourself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't do it. (staring at mirror) I won't testify against my partner or anyone else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This man is a disgrace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your badge and gun, Officer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud sets them on The Chief's desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the new L.A.P.D., White. You're suspended from duty and dismissed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turning, White shoots the mirror a stiff middle finger as he makes his way out.  Dudley Smith hides a smile.

dialogues.speaker: OTHER SIDE OF GLASS
dialogues.text: Exley watches, involuntarily leans back as Bud passes on the other side of the glass.

dialogues.speaker: THE CHIEF'S OFFICE
dialogues.text: Dudley, Loew and The Chief wait as Exley enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed, your observations have been astute.  What's your assessment of this situation?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The public demands justice, sir. This was a full-fledged riot of policemen.  Shift the guilt to men whose pensions are secured.  Force them to retire.  But someone has to swing.  Indict, try and convict Stensland and Bud White.  Secure them jail time.  Feed them to the sharks, sir.  Protect yourself; protect the department.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dudley gives Exley a look.  He's angry with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stensland's a disgrace.  Straight D fitness reports from every C.O. he ever served under.  But White is a valuable officer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: White's a mindless thug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Edmund.  He's a man who can answer yes to those questions I ask you from time to time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Chief interrupts with his own concern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to know who we give the public in contrast?  The department needs role models. Clean-cut, forthright men the public can admire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll testify, sir.  I'm not afraid to do what's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I'll promote you.  You'll be a lieutenant immediately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exley seizes the moment, going over Dudley's head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Detective lieutenant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Chief and Dudley exchange a look.  Neither approves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed, you're 30.  Your father didn't make lieutenant until he was 33.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know that, sir.  I also know that when he made lieutenant, it was as a detective.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Before we start polishing our laurels, it would look better if we had a corroborative witness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That'll be hard to come by.  The men hate a turncoat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack Vincennes.  He's the technical advisor on 'Badge of Honor,' sir.  He lives for it. That's the way to get him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, Ed. (into desk intercom) Call Sergeant Vincennes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Exley starts out, Dudley pulls him aside, speaks low.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll reap the benefits, but are you truly prepared to be despised within the department?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Dudley.  I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So be it.

dialogues.speaker: JACK VINCENNES
dialogues.text: Looking sharp, he strides down the hall, enters the...

dialogues.speaker: CHIEF'S OFFICE
dialogues.text: Round two.  Centred on Jack.  Exley is gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sergeant, we'll get right to it. Nine civilian witnesses have identified you as hitting Ezekiel Garcia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But my office has a stellar witness who will tell the grand jury that you hit back only after being hit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do I have to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Testify against the three officers who have already earned their pensions.  Our key witness will testify roundly, but you can plead ignorance to questions directed at the other men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll guarantee you a slap on the wrist.  A brief suspension followed by a temporary transfer from Narcotics to Ad Vice. (a beat) When you transfer out of Vice, you'll be back on the show.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The show, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Badge of Honor, Vincennes.  We need to tone down your profile for a bit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Chief just got Jack where he lives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John, I doubt you've ever drawn a stupid breath.  Don't start now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.  I'll do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smiles all around.  Loew smiles at the two-way.  A move not lost on Jack who wonders who might be on the other side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dismissed, Vincennes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack leaves.  The Chief steps to the mirror, looks through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So be it.  Detective Lieutenant.

dialogues.speaker: OTHER SIDE OF GLASS
dialogues.text: Exley clenches his fist in victory.  The Chief continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ace them at the grand jury tomorrow, son.  Wear the smart- looking suit and ace them.  And, Ed?  Lose the glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glasses off, Exley waits, looks up as Jack enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the key witness?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should've known.  What's the Chief throwing you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Throwing me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, Exley.  What's the payoff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the payoff expert.  I'm just doing my duty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're playing an angle, college boy.  You're getting something out of this so you don't have to hobnob with the fucking rank and file cops who'll hate your guts for snitching.  If they're making you a detective, watch out.  Some Bureau guys are gonna burn in this and you're gonna have to work with friends of theirs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm snitching three old timers who'll be fishing in Oregon next week.  Next to you I'm clean.  And smart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At that, a CLERK steps in from the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edmund J. Exley to chambers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Exley's about to go...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just remember, Bud White'll fuck you for this if it takes the rest of his life.  They already suspended him.  Just pray he cops a deal and stays on the Department because that is one civilian you do not want on your case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An old black guy in a frayed, threadbare tux plays piano. Bud, nursing a highball at the bar, steps over to a REDHEAD with too much make-up on too many miles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That an old fashioned you're drinking? (as she nods) My name's Bud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody was born with the name Bud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stick you with a name like Wendell, you look for an alias.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you do, Bud?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorta between jobs.  Look, what do you say we, uh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hand on Bud's shoulder.  He turns to see Dudley Smith.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lad, may I have a word with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This business, Captain?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say goodnight to your friend and join me by those back tables.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dudley starts off.  Bud turns back to Redhead, but she's already talking to a sailor.

dialogues.speaker: BOOTH
dialogues.text: Dudley sits at a table.  A newspaper is opened, a little mound underneath.  Bud joins Dudley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does that paper say we've been indicted?  Does it say Exley's a hero for squealing me and Stensland off?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He made his play amd he got what he wanted.  They're making him a detective.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain, what do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call me Dudley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dudley, what do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lad, I admire your refusal to testify and your loyalty to your partner.  I admire you as a policeman, particularly your adherence to violence as a necessary adjutant to the job. And I am most impressed with your punishment of wife beaters.  Do you hate them, Wendell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks away) Yeah, I hate them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And for good reason judging from what I know of your background.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud looks back over.  Dudley's getting too personal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going to happen to Stensland?  He'll give himself cirrhosis over this.  He's one year from his pension.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It would've happened years ago if you hadn't carried him.  Why the loyalty, Wendell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He helped me out once.  That's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your partner's through. Department scapegoat on the Chief's orders.  He's been billed, he'll be indicted and he'll swing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Him and me both.  Fucking Exley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't underestimate his skills. As a politician he exceeds even myself.  But the department needs smart men like Exley and... direct men like yourself

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wendell, I want you to come to work for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doing what?  Mowing your fucking lawn?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smith yanks the newspaper revealing Bud's badge & .38 Special.  Bud can't believe his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're yours.  Take them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew you had juice, but... There's no goddamn bill on me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four of the defendants recanted their testimony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dudley dismisses the question with a wave of his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need you for an assignment the Chief's given me the go-ahead on. A duty few men are fit for, but you were born for.  You'll be working out of Homicide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (excited) Homicide?  A detective?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your talents lie elsewhere, Wendell.  It's a muscle job and shooting job.  You'll do what I say and not ask questions.  Do you follow my drift?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disappointed) In Technicolor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you work for me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course... But how?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How what, Wendell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd you get them to retract?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dudley lays brass knuckles on the table.  They're chipped, caked with blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over the pop song "STRANGER IN PARADISE."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank Sinatra at the premiere of From Here to Eternity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charlie "Bird" Parker makes magic before an appreciative, mostly black crowd.

dialogues.speaker: C
dialogues.text: Nate Janklow exits with his latest flame.  A mob lieutenant, Nate was last seen with Mickey Cohen outside the Federal Courthouse in the opening montage.  A CAR SCREECHES up.  TWO GUNS aim and Nate and his date do down in a proverbial HAIL OF LEAD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A groundbreaking.  The Mayor scrapes at the ground with a gold shovel.  Pierce Patchett is among the distinguished guests.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The marquee gushes:  "Today Sgt. Joe Reno:  Badge of Honor Star Brett Chase."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A nerdy 14-YEAR-OLD asks Brett Chase:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why'd you become a policeman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not a policeman.  I just play one on television.  But I think I can answer for them.  To help people.  That's why I do the show.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chase looks over and winks at Jack who waits in the wings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To protect and serve.  It's not just a motto.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the kids applaud, Chase joins Jack who gives him a quick drag of a cigarette.  A nervous PA joins them. Chase points out a fetching girl in the second row.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That one.  In the sweater. (to Jack) They also serve who only stand and wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chase and Jack watch the PA ask "Sweater" a question while pointing to Chase.  Maybe sixteen, she nods "yes" eagerly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack, I'll see you Monday on set.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't be there.  They're toning down my profile.

dialogues.speaker: PRINTING PRESS
dialogues.text: The latest issue of Hush-Hush flies through.  On the cover:  "Gail Russell Caught In Love Nest.  Nymph or No?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud White flips through today's booking slips, finds one that's interesting.  Reading to himself...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Domestic.  Assault and battery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Containment Squad strong-arms, BREUNING and CARLISLE pause as they pass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ready to go, Bud?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be there in five minutes.

dialogues.speaker: CITY JAIL
dialogues.text: Bud walks to a door covered in sheet metal.  He opens it to reveal a holding tank with a burly, jumpsuited PRISONER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hear you like to hit women.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My wife.  She's dropping charges so it's none of your business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud enters, closes the door behind him.  A beat, we hear the sounds of FISTS ON FLESH.  It's Bud's business now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deuce Perkins (the Mickey Cohen narcotics lieutenant seen earlier) stands at the bookshelf.  He pulls down books to reveal a shoe box.  He sets it on his desk, pulls back the cover to reveal several bags of white powder. Heroin. A BRANCH SNAPS outside.  Perkins opens a drawer, fishes a revolver.  Turning off the light, he heads to the window. His finger parts the curtains.  At that instant, he staggers, falls as GUNFIRE rips into him. The heroin just sits there on the desk. EXT. McNEIL PENITENTIARY - DAY Grim-faced guards scan the yard from machine-gunned towers. INT. McNEIL PENITENTIARY - VISITOR BOOTH - DAY Mickey Cohen sits across from visitor Johnny Stompanato. Cohen is going off the handle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean Deuce Perkins got clipped last night?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They shot him in his library.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want a floor plan; I want to know who!  Who's taking the ticket for this, Johnny?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody.  At least not yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what about the merchandise Deuce was holding for me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gone.  Not a trace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some ferstunkener is moving in and we don't know who?!  Maybe we should ask Hedda Hopper!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As "STRANGER IN PARADISE" ENDS, so does the MONTAGE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Addressing the squad, a no-nonsense VICE CAPTAIN picks up a stack of magazines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Picture-book smut, gentlemen. There's been a bunch of it found at collateral crime scenes lately. Mostly narcotics and prostitution collars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the Vice Capt. hands it out for the men to examine, new member Jack Vincennes arrives late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look who's back from suspension. We're honored, Sergeant Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men laugh.  Jack sits, flips a magazine.  Men and women.  Men and men.  Girls and girls.  Girls and horses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gee.  The Great Jerk-Off Book Caper of 1953.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vincennes, is there someplace you'd rather be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, Cap.  Back in Narcotics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh?  Anyplace else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Working whores with squad two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you should have thought of that before you made Bloody Christmas page one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vice Capt. retrieves the magazines, hands them to Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're yours.  Make a major case, Sergeant.  It's the only way you're getting out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exaggerated "oohs" and "aahs" from the men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dismissed, gentlemen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they go, Jack sees the books are stamped:  "Fleur-de-L Whatever you desire."  Jack takes the matching business card from his wallet, the one he found on Christmas Eve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roll, Vincennes.  No sidetracks. This is Ad Vice, not Narco.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack Vincennes is at his desk.  Holding the Fleur-de-Lis card, magazines spread before him, Jack dials the number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sid Hudgeons sits behind his desk, answers the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hush-Hush.  Off the record and on the Q.T.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sid, it's Vincennes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie, are you back on Narco?  I need copy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INTERCUT WITH Jack at his desk:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  But I've got something going with Ad Vice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something good?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't know.  I'm chasing picture books.  Fuck shots, but the posers don't look like junkies.  It's well done stuff.  I thought you might have heard something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hudgeons reaches into a stack of papers, pulls out a magazine like the one Jack has.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about Fleur-de-Lis?  Their slogan's 'Whatever you desire.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  No, I've heard bupkis.  Jack, I'll talk to you later.  Call me when you get something I can use. Smut's from hunger.  For sad sacks who can't get their ashes hauled

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The LINE CLICKS off.  Jack hesitates a moment before cradling the receiver.  Something's not right here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Exley pulls in, his two-way drones:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Park Rangers report three Negro youths discharging shotguns into the air in Griffith Park. Suspects are driving a late model purple Mercury Coupe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the report ends, Exley switches off the two-way and gets out of his car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Accompanied by Bud, Dick Stensland crams the contents of his desk into a box.  Well-wishing cops pat him on the back, offer words of encouragement, but Stensland looks like he's going to cry. It's very bad timing as Exley enters, comes face-to-face with them.  This is hatred. Acting on impulse, Bud goes after Exley.  It's a mauling. Four vicious body shots.  A potentially lethal head shot sails wide as Exley falls to the ground. As four men move to hold Bud back, Exley looks up at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gasping) You're just a thug, White.  That's all you'll ever be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dudley steps into the fray.  He helps Exley to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should stay away from a man when his blood is up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His blood's always up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four cops are genuinely having trouble holding Bud back. Dudley watches with something bordering on admiration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then maybe you should stay away from him all the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Accompanied by Bud, Stensland reaches his car, loads his box of stuff into the trunk.  Bud is moody, pensive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't look so down in the mouth, Bud.  You nailed him good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, sure... I got a couple of hours before I have to be at the Victory.  Want to grab a beer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rain check me, partner.  I got something big going on tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?  That new mystery girl you've been seeing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  I'll tell you sometime.  Not now.  Don't want to jinx it.  But it could take the edge off that jail time I got coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's confidential, Bud.  Like that magazines Vincennes scams for. Hush-Hush. (smiles) I'll see you tomorrow.  And hey, if it works out, you'll get a piece of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stensland gets in the car, drives off.  Bud is left alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exley sits alone in a sea of desks.  The SQUAWK BOX DRONES.  Exley squints at the clock on the wall, can't make it out.  He takes his glasses from the inside of his jacket.  2:00 A.M.  Finally, something to do.  He walks to the wall calendar, tears off Feb. 28 to reveal Mar. 1. As Exley sits, the call SQUAWK BOX booms to life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Squad call!  Nite Owl Coffee Shop One-eight-one-two-four Cherokee! Multiple homicides!  Multiple homicides!  Code three!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrol cars.  Blues setting up a crime scene blockade. Exley pulls up, DOUSES his SIREN.  PATROLMAN #1 runs over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loads of people down.  Men. Women.  I stopped for coffee --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exley pushes him aside, heads for the door.  It's wide open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exley takes mental snapshots.  Ten stools front a counter.  The side wall mural-papered:  winking owls perched on street signs.  On the right a string of tables.  Three in disarray.  Food spilled, dishes broken. A high-heel pump by an upended chair. Heel drag marks across the linoleum floor heading back toward the kitchen.  Exley follows.  Past an open, empty cash register.  Outside -- SIRENS.

dialogues.speaker: SERVICE RUNWAY
dialogues.text: Crisscrossed drag marks connect, lead to a walk-in...

dialogues.speaker: FOOD LOCKER
dialogues.text: Blood-soaked bodies on the floor.  Five, maybe six in a tangle.  Dozens of shotgun shells float in the pools of blood.  As Exley struggles to maintain his composure...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holy shit fuck...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exley looks at a green-faced ROOKIE in the locker doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: S-s-sir, there's a captain outside wants to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't get sick!  Not in here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exley shoves the Rookie, puking, out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patrolmen hold back a swarm of reporters and rubber- neckers.  HORNS BLAST.  Motorcycles run interference for meat wagons cut off by the crown.  As Ed emerges, reporters surge, shout questions.  Exley hurries past, finds Dudley in command and barking orders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, I took the call.  It's my case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edmund, you don't want it and you can't have it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I do, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's mine.  I'll make you my second in command.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exley spots a photographer moving in.  He looks properly serious as the flash bulb pops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forensics Chief RAY PINKER walks Exley and Dudley through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got a total of forty-five spent 12-gauge Remington shotgun shells. Three men with five-shot-capacity pumps.  All of them reloading twice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold on... We need to canvass. See if a purple Mercury was seen around here tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got a call earlier on three Negro youths.  Firing shotguns in Griffith Park from a late-model purple Mercury Coupe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to his adjutant) Get on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A FORENSICS COP approaches Pinker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got an I.D. on one of the victims, sir... I think it's Dick Stensland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exley and Dudley react, look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Set in a no-man's-land of bulldozed homes.  A sign proudly announces the impending arrival of the freeway. The motel is surrounded by a barbed-wire fence. Abandoned but for a pair of LAPD cars and a light burning in room 6. An unmarked pulls up and Exley and Dudley step out.  They start forward, but a SCREAM inside 6 stops Exley short.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With Mickey Cohen in prison, Los Angeles is organized crime free. The Chief wants it to stay that way, Edmund.  The means are not for the weak-hearted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bare.  A table and chair bolted to the floor.  A tough FLAT-NOSED GANGSTER is cuffed to the hot seat.  On the table are a .45 and a fat roll of $100 bills. Breuning and Carlisle watch as Bud White delivers a couple of short, stiff body shots.  Flatnose is not used to being on the receiving end.  All the same, we get the idea Bud's a bit reluctant. Bud's back is to Dudley and Exley who enter behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come, Wendell, you can do better than that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud turns, sees Exley and Dudley.  A beat.  As Bud looms over Flatnose, the gangster babbles.  Snitch-frenzied.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know things.  I hear things. Like with the Mick inside, things are on this weird slowdown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These shooter teams, bang bang bang, they're 86-ing Mickey Cohen's men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We know all that, lad.  Tell us, who do these shooters work for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.  No one knows. Maybe they're mavericks.  You want a prostie roust?  Huh?  Some narco action? (breaking down) What do you want?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We want you to go home. (to Breuning) Uncuff him, Michael.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dudley turns to Exley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Sifakis is a known loan shark from San Francisco.  He arrived this afternoon at Union Station. Looking for business opportunities in our fair city.  An organized crime associate in need of re- education in the ways of polite society.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uncuffed, Flatnose rubs his wrists.  Wary.  As Breuning steps back, Flatnose snatches the .45 off the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Motherfuckers!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exley dives for cover, but the other four cops just stand there.  Dudley looks down on the floor at Exley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's part of the play, Edmund.  A sincerity test.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flatnose looks at the gun a beat, then squeezes the TRIGGER.  CLICK CLICK.  No bullets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Breuning) Sit him back down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLICK, CLICK.  They shove Flatnose back in the hot seat. Dudley offers a hand to Exley, helps him to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wendell, you need to accompany Detective Lieutenant Exley on official police business.  I'll finish up here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They drive in silence.  No love lost here.  Finally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are we going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a surprise.  You like surprises, don't you, White?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exley pulls up.  Bud looks to him.  Really curious now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exley and Bud walk.  An orderly wheels a covered corpse toward them from the other end of the hall.  Bud's spooked.  The orderly wheels the body in to the examination room. As Bud and Exley pass, the CORONER pulls back the sheet, is surprised at the sight of a woman who we don't quite see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call me crazy, but for a second I thought it was Rita Hayworth.

dialogues.speaker: MORGUE MEAT LOCKER
dialogues.text: Exley and Bud walk past a wall of drawers to where a coroner's assistant waits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We need you to I.D. the body. There's no next of kin and you knew him best.  So tell me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The assistant pulls open drawer 12.  A naked man. A tag on his toe and half his face blown off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that Dick Stensland?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stunned, Bud stares at what's left of his old partner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, that's Stens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell of a way to avoid a prison sentence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud's torn between wanting to smash Exley and finding out why Stensland is dead.  He squeezes out the words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone held up a coffee shop, panicked and killed six people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then, from the hall...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not my baby!  Not my little girl!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HILDA LEFFERTS, 50, enters with the coroner to ID the body of her daughter, Susan. There's stray buckshot in the upper chest and shoulders, but a sheet hides the real damage.  It's the girl Bud saw outside Hollywood Liquor.  Without the black eyes, she does look like Rita hayworth. As Bud and Exley appear, Mrs. Lefferts looks confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this your daughter, Mrs. Lefferts?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I -- I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We know this is difficult.  Just take your time and look again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exley doesn't realize, but Bud recognizes the deceased.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It seems like my Susan, but...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When was the last time you saw her, Mrs. Lefferts?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At Christmas.  We had fought.  I didn't like her boyfriend.  I -- she has a birthmark on her hip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Coroner lifts the sheet.  Mrs. Lefferts gasps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's her.  My baby.  Dear God...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Mrs. Lefferts swoons, Bud and Exley both hold her up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room buzzes, jammed to the rafters with every detective standing ready.  The Chief waits as Dudley Smith takes the mike, holds up an L.A. Times headline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Nite Owl Massacre.'  Hyperbole aside, this is a heinous crime that requires a swift resolution. The public will demand it and this department will provide it.  Six victims.  One of them, one of our own -- Dick Stensland. (as the cops react) As it happens, he was a Nite Owl regular.  In the wrong place at the wrong time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud White listens, not too sure.  Stensland said he had something big going on...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Robbery looks like the motive.  We have rubber glove prints on the register and preliminary forensics strongly lean toward a trio of gunmen.  We do have one hot lead, so listen well.  Three Negro youths were seen last night discharging shotguns in the air at Griffith Park. A park ranger I.D.ed them as driving a 1948 to 1950 Mercury Coupe, purple in color.  An hour ago, a canvassing crew found a news vendor who saw a purple Merc Coupe parked across from the Nite Owl around 3:00 A.M.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room goes loud, a big rumbling.  Dudley holds up a list.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The D.M.V. worked all night to get us a registration list on '48 to '50 purple Mercs.  There are 142 registered to Negroes in L.A. County.  Fifty two-man teams will shake three names apiece.  Hot suspects you'll bring here. Interrogation rooms have been set up.  They'll be run by Lieutenant Edmund Exley.  Hollywood Squad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Catcalls.  Boos.  The Chief steps to the mike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enough on that.  Gentlemen, just go out and get them.  Use all necessary force.  The people of Los Angeles demand it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men exchange knowing looks.  The real message:  kill them clean.  Exley doesn't approve.  As the men hurry out...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He might as well have put a bounty on them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Detectives pairing up and moving out.  Scanning his three name list, Bud joins his PARTNER for the day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you take them?  I got I got something I gotta do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christ, I don't know.  What if one of these names...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I gotta do is for Stensland. My partner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guy looks at him a beat, nods.  As Bud heads off...

dialogues.speaker: EXLEY
dialogues.text: watches everyone go.  Wishes he could be part of the action.  He spots Jack talking to his REDNECK partner for for the day.

dialogues.speaker: JACK AND REDNECK
dialogues.text: Redneck chews tobacco, has a Texas drawl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where to, Trash?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we go by the list, we have about zero chance of making the collar.  But I know a guy who knows what's going on south of Jefferson.  I'm betting he could put us at 50/50.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Redneck thinks, Exley steps up.  He's overheard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take those odds. (to Redneck) Take off.  We got it from here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack stares.  Redneck shrugs, spits tobacco juice in a cup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Between the two of you guys, you should bring along a photographer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last time we saw the Owner was Christmas Eve.  He looks up from a customer as Bud strides in, badge out front.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need an address on a customer of yours.  Her name was Lynn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all I have to go on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  And I think you already know who I mean, so cough it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lynn Bracken.  There's a billing address and a delivery address.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me both.  Billing first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A big, pink Spanish mansion with lots of tile.  Also last seen outside Hollywood Liquor on Christmas Eve, Pierce Patchett is in the front yard, chipping golf balls over a koi pond.  They land in a tight grouping.  As he tees up:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must slay 'em at the country club.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud's halfway up the walk.  Patchett sees the cuffs hooked to his belt.  Patchett is cool as can be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you Pierce Patchett?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am.  Are you soliciting for police charities?  The last time, you people called at my office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a homicide detective.  Where were you last night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was here, hosting a party.  Who was killed and why do you think I can help?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard Stensland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know him.  Mr...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Officer White.  How about Susan Lefferts?  You know her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sighs, concedes) You know I do or you wouldn't be here.  How did you find me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We met outside Hollywood Liquors on Christmas Eve.  This is where Lynn Bracken's booze bills go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sue Lefferts died at the Nite Owl. I'm investigating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Patchett studies Bud a beat, weighing his options. Patchett's burly BODYGUARD starts over from the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything alright, Mr. Patchett?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (waves him off) Fine, Philip.  Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's the other guy?  Buzz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He no longer works for me. (a beat) Find Susan's killer, Mr. White. I'll give you a handsome reward. Whatever you desire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If only Jack had been around to hear that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, but no thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Against your code?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have one.  Lefferts looked beat-up Christmas Eve, but didn't act it.  How come?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you care about criminal matters peripheral to Susan's murder?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you wouldn't feel obligated to report them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then listen closely, because I'll only say this once and if it gets repeated, I'll deny it.  I run call girls.  Lynn Bracken is one of them and so was Susan Lefferts. I treat my girls very well.  I have grown daughters, myself, and I don't like the thought of women being hurt.  I sense you share this feeling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ignores comment) Why were Lefferts' eyes black?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think she'd been hit in the face with a tennis racket.  She is -- was -- a big doubles fan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wanna go downtown and discuss this officially?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait.  Our deal still holds?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud nods, his patience running thin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I needed a Rita Hayworth to fill out my little studio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What little studio?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's Gardner, Hepburn, Grable, Turner.  Lynn Bracken is my Veronica Lake.  I use girls who look like movie stars.  Sometimes I employ a plastic surgeon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why her mother couldn't I.D. her... Jesus fucking Christ.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Mr. White.  Pierce Morehouse Patchett.  Now, I sense you're on your best behavior, but that's all I'll give you.  If you persist, I'll meet you with my attorney. Now, would you like Miss Bracken's address?  I doubt she knows anything, but --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got her address.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course... this is personal with you, isn't it, Mr. White?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud turns, heads down the walk.  Patchett hits his golf ball.  It lands just past the koi pond, with the rest. Ice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A modern-looking triplex.  A projector's flicker strobes against the closed curtains.  We hear a PHONE RING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The film is This Gun For Hire with Alan Ladd and Veronica Lake.  It's projected on a wall in front of which stands Lynn Bracken and an OLDER GENTLEMAN, in his underwear. Lynn's long, blonde hair hangs down over one eye.  She looks more like Veronica Lake than Veronica Lake.  The film flashes over them as they kiss. The PHONE RINGS.  Lynn ignores it as long as she can before breaking away to go answer it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Alan Ladd) Is it the cops?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She waves him off.  As he practices pointing his finger like Ladd points a gun, Lynn reacts to the news on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A South Central plywood and tar-paper dive.  A BLACK BOXER pounds a heavy bag/speed bag combo bolted to the porch.  Wiry, a welterweight, he doesn't see Jack and Exley till they're almost on top of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leonard Bidwell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Boxer leans on the bag to catch his breath.  Looking them over, he finally nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's the left these days?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's it to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw you fight Kid Gavilan.  I like your style.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want, Mr. Policeman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a brother up in Folsom.  I know because I put him there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Till 19-fucking-70.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd you like to make it 1960?  I know the judge and Sergeant Exley here is friends with hte D.A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exley nods, this is true.  The Boxer's still listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're looking for three colored guys who like to pop off shotguns. One of 'em owns a purple Merc coupe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wanna get me a fuckin' snitch jacket?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wanna buy your brother ten years...?  You don't have to say anything.  Just look at this list and point.  Here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack holds the DMV list out to the Boxer, who waves it off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's bad, so I'll just tell you. Sugar Ray Coates.  Drives a '49 coupe, a beautiful ride.  Don't know about shotguns, but he gets his thrills killing dogs.  He is righteous trash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack and Exley scan the list.  Jack's finger stabs down on, "Coates, Raymond, 9611 South Central, Room 414."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's five minutes from here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lynn does her best to usher the slightly disheveled Older Gentleman out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand, doll, we just got started.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, but I'll make it up to you.  I promise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gosh, kitten, I don't know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
