dialogues.text: As he begins to mash up against her...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hit the road, gramps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud's standing at the bottom of the stairs.  The Older Gentleman strikes a pose.  He still thinks he's Alan Ladd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright.  This time I'll go, but next time --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flips badge) L.A.P.D., shitbird.  Get the fuck out of here or I'll call your wife to come get you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sputtering, the Older Gentleman exchanges a look with Lynn then hurries away, giving Bud a wide berth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been expecting you.  Pierce called.  Told me what happened to Sue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A nice breezy feel.  The perfect place to shack up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Officer White, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud nods, eyeballs the place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I get you a drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, plain scotch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud watches her move to the bar.  God, she's beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was friendly with Sue Lefferts, but we weren't really friends. You know what I mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sorry she's dead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course I am.  What kind of question is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She steps back with a scotch for both of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you ever heard of Dick Stensland?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No I haven't.  Do you know why Pierce is humoring you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You use words like that, you might make me mad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  But do you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah I know.  Patchett's running whores and judging by his address, probably something bigger on the side.  He doesn't want any attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.  Our motives are selfish, so we're cooperating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why was Susan Lefferts at the Nite Owl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.  I never heard of the Nite Owl till today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did Lefferts have a boyfriend?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like I said we were friendly, not friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd she meet Patchett?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pierce meets people.  Sue came on the bus with dreams of Hollywood.  This is how they turned out.  Thanks to Pierce, we still get to act a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me about Patchett.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's waiting for you to mention mention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want some advice, Miss Bracken?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Lynn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Bracken, don't ever try to fucking bribe me or threaten me or I'll have you and Patchett in shit up to your ears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lynn smiles again.  She likes Bud.  A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I remember you from Christmas Eve.  You have a thing for helping women, don't you, Officer White?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I'm just fucking curious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You say 'fuck' a lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You fuck for money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's blood on your shirt.  Is that an integral part of your job?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you enjoy it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When they deserve it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did they deserve it today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you did it anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, just like the half dozen guys you screwed today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs again) Actually, it was two.  You're different, Officer White.  You're the first man in five years who didn't tell me I look like Veronica Lake inside of a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look better than Veronica Lake.  Now, Pierce Patchett.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes a cut of our earnings and invests it for us.  He makes us quit the life at thirty.  He doesn't let us use narcotics and he doesn't abuse us.  Can your policeman's mentality grasp those contradictions?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He had you cut to look like Veronica Lake?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  I'm really a brunette, but the rest is me.  And that's all the news that's fit to print.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lynn starts toward the door.  Bud watches her a moment, then follows.  She takes his glass at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was nice meeting you, Officer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out the door, Bud turns back.  Blurts:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look.  I want to see you again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you asking me for a date or an appointment?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly unsure) I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (another smile) If it's a date I think you'd better tell me your first name because I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (feeling foolish) Forget I asked.  It was a mistake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lynn watches thoughtfully after Bud as he walks away. He opens his car door like he's going to tear ir off. A last glance back at Lynn and as he gets in the car...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An L-shaped walk-up.  Jack coasts the car to the curb. He leaps out with Exley.  Exley holds up at the sight of a late model sedan.  He leans down to look in the window at the two-way on the dash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: L.A.P.D.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit.  Someone beat us here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VOICES from the carport ahead.  We see a chrome bumper, the purple fender of a '49 Mercury coupe.  A door slams. Drawing a .45, Jack starts over with Exley, .38 in hand.

dialogues.speaker: CARPORT
dialogues.text: Toting shotguns, Dudley's boys from the Victory Motel, Breuning and Carlisle, stand by the purple Mercury.  Jack and Exley come around the corner, lower their guns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Breuning wheels, pumps a round into the chamber.  He very nearly fires before he sees who it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the fuck are you guys doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think of us as back-up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you got?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Jack moves to peer through the Merc's window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three Ithaca pumps, an empty box of double-ought buck and cash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack spots them.  Three shotguns on the passenger side floor, an empty box of shells and loose dollar bills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So long, Vice.  Badge of Honor, here I come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you, Vincennes.  It's our collar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Breuning actually has to restrain his partner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quiet.  I'm ranking officer here. We go as a team.  End of story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Breuning and Carlisle lead the way with Jack and Exley bringing up the rear.  Squinting, Exley reaches to his pocket for something.  Not there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damnit...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (chuckling) Just don't shoot me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door to 414.  Two men on either side.  Breuning rears back.  Jack rears back.  They kick at the same instant. The door flies off its hinges to reveal two young black men, LARRY FONTAINE and TY JONES, waking from a couple of flop mattresses.

dialogues.speaker: ROOM 414
dialogues.text: Fontaine jumps up.  Entering, Carlisle aims, but Exley grabs his arm.  The BLAST rips the ceiling.  Jack aims.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Freeze!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fontaine freezes.  Jones doesn't dare get up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ace him, Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up, Carlisle!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack and Exley burst into a...

dialogues.speaker: SECOND BEDROOM
dialogues.text: Another black, RAY COATES, passed out on mattress, sur- rounded by empty beer cans.  Jack sticks his .38 in his back, starts to cuff him.  As the cuff ratchets down...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dudley watches intently as Ed Exley skims a report, memorizing names and dates.  Jack and other brass are also here along with a stenographer.  So's Bud.  One of these guys killed Stensland.  Through tinted glass, the three suspects in three different rooms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Casitas Youth Camp... Coates twenty-two, a boxer... Manager saw them burning clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Satisfied, Exley sets the report down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed, I want confessions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll break them, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Exley steps into the #1 room, Jack joins Dudley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think golden boy can handle it, Cap?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you'll be surprised what Edmund's capable of.

dialogues.speaker: INT.
dialogues.text: Exley closes the door.  Ray Coates is cuffed to a chair, dressed in baggy County denims.  One eye swollen shut, lip split, a smashed nose with one nostril split. Exley unlocks his cuffs. drops cigarettes and amtches on the table.  As Coates rubs his wrists...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They call you Sugar Ray because of Ray Robinson? (no answer) They say Robinson can throw a four punch combination in one second.  Do you believe that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coates just stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're twenty-two, aren't you, Ray?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say what and so what.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did one of the officers work you over a little?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No bite.  Coates just stares back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look like Robinson after that last LaMotta fight.  'Course LaMotta looked a lot worse.  So you're twenty-two, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, why do you keep asking me that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just getting my facts straight. Twenty-two makes it a gas chamber bounce. You should have pulled this caper a couple of years ago.  Get life, do a little Youth Authority jolt, transfer to Folsom a big man. Orbit on some of that good prison brew, get yourself a sissy --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never truck with no sissies!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That fucking Larry.  I almost believed him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Believed what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing, Ray. (laughs) That Larry, he's a pisser.  You did the Casitas Youth Camp with him, didn't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, why're you talkin' about Larry?  His business is his business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unseen by Coates, Exley reaches under the table, takes hold of one of three toggle switches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sugar, Larry told me you went sissy up at Casitas.  You couldn't do the time so you found yourself a big white boy to look after you.  He said they call you 'Sugar' because you gave it out so sweet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exley flips the toggle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The speaker over Larry Fontaine's head crackles to life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry gave it at Casitas!  Man, I was the fuckin' boss jocker on my dorm!  Larry's the sissy! Larry gave it for candy bars!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exley flips up the second toggle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray, you protected Ty and Larry up in Casitas, didn't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ain't woofin' I did.  Stupid down home niggers got no more sense than a fuckin' dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exley flips the switches off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard you like to shoot dogs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dogs got no reason to live.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh?  you feel that way about people, too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, what're you saying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray, we got the shotguns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't own no shotguns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why were you throwing clothes in the building incinerator?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trembling) Say what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You guys were arrested this morning, but none of you have last night's clothes.  You were seen burning them.  Add to that the fact that you hid the car you were cruising around in last night and it doesn't look good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got nothin' more to say till I see a judge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were you on hop?  You were passed out when you got arrested.  Were you hopped up, Ray?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ty and Larry fuck with that shit, not me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where do they get their stuff? Come on.  Give me one to feed the D.A.  Just a little one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coates nods.  Exley flips up the toggles as he leans in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roland Navarette.  Lives on Bunker Hill.  He runs a hole-up for parole absconders and sells red devils.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exley flips down the switches, stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to take a break.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exley opens the door, looks back in afterthought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, Ray, I'm talking about the gas chamber and you haven't even asked me what this is all about.  You got a big guilty sign around your neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exley exits.

dialogues.speaker: OBSERVATION ROOM
dialogues.text: Exley enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Masterful, Edmund.  Your father would've been proud. (pointing) This one's on the verge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exley looks through the glass into #2.  Larry Fontaine is weeping.  A piss puddle on the floor by his chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fontaine next, but give Jones the newspaper.  I want him primed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fontaine tries to control his sniffles as Exley enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry, Ray Coates ratted you off.  He said the Nite Owl was your idea.  You want to tell me about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it was Ray's idea.  Talk and I think I can save your life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry, this is a gas chamber job. If you don't talk, you'll be dead in six months.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Son, six people are dead and somebody has to pay.  It can be you or it can be Ray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry, he called you queer.  He said at Casitas you took it up the ass.  He said --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I DIDN'T KILL NOBODY!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The voice is strong, full of conviction.  Exley glances at the mirror.  Then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why'd you burn the clothes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sobbing) I just wanted to lose my cherry. I didn't mean to hurt her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exley can't hide his surprise at this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hurt who?  Was she a hooker? Hurt who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Fontaine is gone.  Head lolling, eyes squeezing out tears.

dialogues.speaker: OBSERVATION ROOM
dialogues.text: Exley steps out of the interrogation room.  Dudley braces him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't get sidetracked.  Stay with the Nite Owl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She may still be alive, whoever she is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud's all ears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reading, Jones has his feet on the table.  Exley bursts in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This newspaper shit ain't shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's the girl?  Did you kill her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No answer, but Jones looks nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wanted Larry to lose his cherry, but things got out of hand.  Is that right?

dialogues.speaker: OBSERVATION ROOM
dialogues.text: Everyone's attention is riveted, particularly Bud's. They watch, listen over the speaker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over speaker) Kick loose, Jones.  I know you made her bleed, but that doesn't mean you killed her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No answer, but Jones is squirming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over speaker) If that girl's alive, you've still got a chance on this one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over speaker) I think she's alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over speaker) You think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack turns to Dudley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's good.  I'll give him that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't notice as the chair back begins to splinter in Bud's hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exley sits across from him, tries to wrap it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is she now? (no answer) Did you leave her someplace? (no answer) Did you sell her out?  Give her to some of your buddies?  Tell me where the girl is!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door blasts open.  Bud slams Jones up against the wall.  As Exley stands, he bangs his knee on the table. Pulling a .38, Bud breaks the cylinder, drops 5 shells on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One in six.  Where's the girl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Officer White, put down that weapon and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud shoves the barrel into Jones' mouth, pulls the trigger twice.  CLICK, CLICK.  Jones starts to slide down the wall.  Bud jerks him back up, roars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHERE?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two more clicks.  Jones spills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: S-sylvester F-fitch one-o-nine and Avalon gray corner house...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A four cordon.  They coast up to a GRAY CORNER HOUSE. Dudley Smith behind the wheel of the lead cruiser.  Bud White rides shotgun, reloading his revolver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me one minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got it, Wendell.

dialogues.speaker: STREET
dialogues.text: Bud is out the door and scooting down an alley.  Exley moves to follow, but Dudley cuts him off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're going through the front.

dialogues.speaker: ALLEY
dialogues.text: Bud vaults a fence, pads up the back porch.  A screen door.  Bud slips the catch with a penknife and walks inside.

dialogues.speaker: SCREEN PORCH
dialogues.text: Bud heads for a blind-covered door.  Unlocked, he enters...

dialogues.speaker: A HALLWAY
dialogues.text: Light bouncing from side rooms.  We hear the opening spiel of "Badge of Honor" from the left.  Bud wheels into a...

dialogues.speaker: BEDROOM
dialogues.text: A NUDE GIRL spread-eagled on a mattress.  Bound with neckties.  One in her mouth.  Her eyes grow wide at the sight of Bud, then flicker to the adjoining room. Directing him.  Raising the .38, Bud enters...

dialogues.speaker: THE KITCHEN
dialogues.text: Sylvester Fitch sits naked at the table wolfing Rice Krispies and watching "Badge of Honor" on a flickering TV.  He looks up, sees the .38 before he sees Bud beyond it.  Fitch drops his spoon, raises his hands. Bud SHOOTS him in the face.  Dead, Fitch just sits there. Bud moves behind him.  Pulling a spare piece from an ankle holster, Bud FIRES back at the door from Fitch's line of fire, then puts the gun in Fitch's hand. We hear the FRONT DOOR CRASH OPEN.  As Fitch slides off the chair to the floor, Bud dumps the Rice Krispies on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Girl on a stretcher.  Being carried to an AMBULANCE. Bud White walks alongside, looking like some ferocious pet pit bull.  The ATTENDANTS get her inside.  One joins her.  The other closes the door, pauses to light a smoke. Bud rips the cigarette out of his mouth, nearly taking the guy's lips with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get her to the fucking hospital.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One look at Bud, and the Attendant is running around to the driver's side.  Exley arrives, steamed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A naked guy with a gun?  You expect anyone to believe that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get the fuck away from me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud starts away, but Exley gets right in his face.  Other cops begin to take notice.  The ambulance pulls out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's it going to look on your report?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll look like justice.  That's what that fat fuck got.  Justice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't know what the word means, you dumb bastard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud goes after Exley, but ten hands pull them apart. Dudley on Exley.  Four cops genuinely having trouble on Bud. And as if things couldn't get crazier, shouts from the cops on the street.  POLICE RADIOS CRANKED UP.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Repeat, three suspects escaped from the Hall of Justice jail. The Nite Owl killers:  Raymond Coates, Tyrone Jones and Larry Fontaine.  They are considered armed and extremely dangerous. Descriptions are as follows...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Electrified, "Nite Owl Killers" on everyone's lips. Exley strides through with purpose, beelines to a filing cabinet.  Exley pulls the file he's looking for.  He scans an interrogation transcript, reads to himself the words he's looking for:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Give me one to feed the D.A.... Roland Navarette.  Lives on Bunker Hill.  Runs a hole-up for parole absconders.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Police rush back and forth.  Exley hurries over to the desk, but he's not there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyone seen Jack Vincennes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few cops mumble they haven't.  As Exley decides what to do, Carlisle from the original arrest steps over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is something up, Lieutenant?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXT.  1ST & OLIVE - DAY Exley and Carlisle pull up across the street from a four-story Victorian with paint peeling off the clap- boards.  They jump out of the car toting SHOTGUNS. Carlisle waits as Exley checks the mail slots: "R. Navarette, 408. "

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exley and Carlisle take the steps two at a time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exley squints, reaches to a pocket.  No glasses.  He passes an elevator, rounds a corner.  There's 408.  Exley pumps the shotgun, nods to Carlisle who kicks the door in.

dialogues.speaker: NAVARETTE LIVING ROOM
dialogues.text: Exley and Carlisle burst in on four men eating sandwiches Fontaine and Caucasian NAVARETTE at a table.  Coates on the floor.  Jones by the window.  Exley squints.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody move!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fontaine and Navarette raise their hands.  A jostled BEER BOTTLE CRASHES to the floor.  Reacting, Carlisle JERKS the TRIGGER.  Fontaine goes down. Navarette draws a .38, SHOOTS Carlisle twice in the chest.  Exley BLASTS Navarette. Screaming, Jones pulls a .45 from his belt.  Exley FIRES, blowing him right THROUGH the WINDOW. Coates draws and FIRES, makes a run for it.  A bad pull takes out half a back wall.  Coates is out the door.

dialogues.speaker: ELEVATOR
dialogues.text: Coates makes it inside, frantically pushes buttons.

dialogues.speaker: HALLWAY
dialogues.text: Here comes Exley.  Stumbling, wiping Navarette's blood out of his eyes, he closes on the...

dialogues.speaker: ELEVATOR
dialogues.text: Coates watches as the elevator doors begin closing.

dialogues.speaker: HALLWAY
dialogues.text: Exley charging.

dialogues.speaker: ELEVATOR
dialogues.text: The shotgun barrel juts through.  The doors bang against it.  BLAM!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TONY BENNETT belts "BOULEVARD OF BROKEN DREAMS."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exley returns to grudging respect.  His white shirt flecked with blood, he's clapped on the back by Dudley who dubs him "Shotgun Ed."  Exley doesn't enjoy it.  He's numb, stumbling along.  As he notices the blood on his hands...

dialogues.speaker: NEWSPAPER HEADLINE
dialogues.text: NITE OWL HERO!  Over a photo of Exley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A coffin is lowered into the ground.  A WIDOW leans on the Chief's arm, accepts a tri-folded American flag from Dudley Smith.  Exley drops a handful of earth on the casket, has trouble getting the wet dirt off his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We mourn the passing of a good man.  The loss of Sgt. William Carlisle is the loss of his wife, his family and the entire Los Angeles Police Department...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sea of dress blues.  Jack looks bored, dressed too flashy for a funeral.  Bud looks grim, rain dripping off the brim of his cap.  As a TWENTY-ONE GUN salute is FIRED...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry Fontaine's mother mourns alone as her son is buried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exley talks with a tough, starchy NURSE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need the girl to give me a chronology of events.  No details. Just times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Absolutely not.  She barely remembers her own name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was told the case was closed. Should I call your superior to double-check?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  that won't be necessary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Nurse turns, marches away.  Exley is left with a nagging doubt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People cheer as bulldozers mow down orange trees.  A banner heralds the future:  "On this site:  The World's Biggest Amusement Park."  Cartoon characters dance among the fallen trees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sitting behind a desk is the Older Gentleman last seen doing his best Alan Ladd impersonation at Lynn Bracken's. He stares emphatically at the SMARMY LAWYER who stands before him holding a manila folder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You tell Mr. Patchett I have no intention of changing my vote.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Lawyer simply hands him a stack of photographs.  From Lynn Bracken's apartment.  The first is the Older Gentleman naked except for his socks and garters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Older Gentleman rises for an assembly vote.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It may surprise some, but a mature man, enlightened by the facts, can change him mind...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rain.  A limo disgorges a heavy-set man who climbs steps, knocks on the door.  Lynn answers in an evening gown.  He gives her a peck on the cheek and continues in past her. Lynn's about to follow him in when she pauses to deadpan a look down the street. Bud's Packard is parked there and we can see his darkened silhouette behind the wheel.  Smiling a bit sadly to herself, Lynn disappears inside. This is no stake-out.  Bud watches after her with yearning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cigarette girls and club photographer make the rounds. Johnny Stompanato enjoys the frenzien floor show.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A horse parade, heavy on the law enforcement contingent, Out of place in his suit and tie, District Attorney Ellis Loew awkwardly rides atop a sleek Palimono.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd in a frenzy as Vincennes-snitch, the welterweight black boxer, beats the shit out of a white fighter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A father holds out his hand, counts along as Jack slaps $100 bills into his palm.  Maybe four thousand dollars. Jack says something about "We appreciate your understanding during this difficult time."  As "Badge of Honor" comes on the TV, the father responds with "Goddamn actors." Leading, Jack looks through an open door where Brett Chase's high school "Sweater Girl" is being comforted by her mother.  As she locks eyes with him an instant...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The monied johns watch horny as hell as "Ginger Rogers" twirls around the room with a female "Fred Astaire." Clothes fly as they spin.  Still, most eyes turn to Lynn Bracken as she enters oozing that cat-girl grace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reporters scribble as the Chief speaks.  Uniforms everywhere along with Exley and Loew.  Bus sits in the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edmund J. Exley has amassed a brilliant record in his seven years with the L.A.P.D.  Recently he evinced spectacular bravery in the line of duty.  It is my honor to present him with our highest honor, the Medal of Valor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exley steps up.  The Chief hangs a gold medallion around his neck.  Flashbulbs pop as the two men shake hands. Exley then accepts a handshake from Dudley.  The policemen stand on cue, applaud without enthusiasm. Dudley lifts the medal from his chest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your father would've been proud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exley uses the noise to have aprivate chat with Dudley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are loose ends out there, Dudley.  I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There always are.  But there are also three men and three guns. Matched forensically.  A few loose ends don't matter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something's wrong.  I feel it inside.  Doesn't that sound crazy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dudley puts an arm around Exley's shoulder, smiles out as more bulbs flash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Breaking a big case sticks you in a whirlwind.  A little self-doubt? It's natural.  Just keep it inside.  Between you and you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exley considers his medal.  It is an appealing thing. In the back, Bud stays sprawled in his seat.  No one's watching as he takes out his gun, kisses it, and blows pretend smoke off the barrel.  As the song ends...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A "Badge of Honor" fund-raiser for D.A. Loew's re- election cmpaign.  Hot dogs and sauerkraut.  Fishbowls stuffed with cash.  Jack is here, returns a smile half- heartedly.  Loew sits with his wife and teenage daughter as Brett "Joe Reno" Chase speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This election is about the future of law enforcement in Los Angeles. Ellis Loew represents that future. So dig deep and let's get a moral man re-elected.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Applause.  Leaving the podium, Chase smiles at Ellis Loew's daughter who absolutely gushes.  Chase then winks knowingly to Jack who returns a tired, humorless smile. Jack scans the room.  An odd moment as Jack catches his own reflection in a mirror across the way.  He puts a hand to his face.  Is that him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big V Jack Vincennes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack turns to see Sid Hudgeons approaching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're back, boychick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sid, how are they hanging?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Down around my ankles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hudgeons scans the crowd, points someone out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You remember Matt Reynolds?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack spots Matt Reynolds -- one of the young actors Jack arrested on Christmas Eve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Grauman's Chinese pot bust. He just got off the honor farm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's he doing here, Sid?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You tight with the D.A., trash?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, he just tried to throw me off the force last Christmas as a little joke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd you like a little payback? Not to mention a donation to the widows and orphans fund.  Did you know Loew was a swish?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Reynolds?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's queer too.  Metro paid him two grand a week to fake it with ingenues.  On screen and off.  I'm getting him to fuck the D.A. for a hundred bucks. (winks) That's twice the fifty you got for wrecking his career.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even Jack's not immune to a comment like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Matt!  Over here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Hudgeons heads over, Hudgeons points out...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's D.A. Loew right there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reynolds gets a nervous bead on Loew.  Hudgeons realizes:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You need a drink, kid... Jack, look after him a minute.  Kid, this is Jack.  No secrets between me and him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hudgeons heads off.  Reynolds, plae, nods at Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have we met before?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack doesn't really feel like talking to him.  Reynolds' nerves won't let him stay quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was it a party?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (misreading) Oh, I know.  A Fleur-de-Lis party, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack remembers the name, plays along for what it's worth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fleaur-de-Lis.  'Whatever you desire.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dope, liquor, hookers that look like movie stars.  Pierce Patchett has it all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack recognizes the name, bluffs for more information.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  Me and Patchett go way back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pierce isn't like regular people. I dig him, but he scares me too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?  How?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shakes his head) You know, when I came out to L.A., this isn't exactly where I saw myself ending up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  Me neither.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reynolds looks like he's going to cry.  Hudgeons returns with a double Scotch straight up and a hot dog with sauerkraut.  He hands the drink to Matt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dutch courage, kid.  Drink up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reynolds downs a few gulps, looks across the room at Loew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know if I should do this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, it's not like you don't know how.  And Jack here has connections on 'Badge of Honor.' Pull this off and there'll be a part for you.  I smell a comeback. Don't you, Jack?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reynolds looks to Jack who gives a noncommittal shrug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loew's free.  Congratulate him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reynolds nods, drains his glass and heads off.  Hudgeons hands Jack a folded slip of paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If Reynolds works his charms, which he will, this is the address where they'll be.  Meet me at midnight.  I guarantee all sorts of illegal activity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hudgeons takes out a President Grant $50 bill.  Jack doesn't take it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sid, why would a guy like Pierce Patchett get involved with running dope and hookers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where'd you hear that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie, all I know is what you know.  The man is very rich.  And he's invested in freeway construction so he's gonna get a lot richer.  But that's it. Patchett's what I like to call 'Twilight.'  He ain't queer, he ain't Red, he can't help me in my quest for prime sinuendo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack takes the $50 as Reynolds returns, shaking his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Talk to him, Jack.  Tell him about the opening on the show.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm pretty sure I can get you a part on the show... But tonight? Pretend it's an acting job, kid. Showbiz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And no one'll know about this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll be our secret.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Showbiz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emboldened by Jack's promise, Reynolds heads off.  Jack and Hudgeons watch as he strikes a conversation with Loew who's captivated.  Hudgeons chomps a bite of his hot dog, gives Jack the high sign, but Jack just feels like a pimp

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Screams.  A cauliflower-eared Cleveland mob enforcer on the hotseat. Breuning works him with a rubber hose as Dudley asks unanswered questions.  Bud watches, revulsion growing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where did you intend to start. Prostitution?  Gambling? (no answer) Go back to Cleveland, lad.  This is the City of Angels and you haven't got any wings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More screams as the hose thwops down.  Bud looks away, then shuffles blindly out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud runs water in the sink to drown out the SCREAMS.  It doesn't work.  Finally, he leans down and sticks his head under the stream of water.  That doesn't work either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hair dripping wet, Bud makes it to his car.  The tires spit gravel as he tears away.  Dudley appears in the doorway, watching curiously.  As cauliflower continues to SCREAM...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud watches Lynn Bracken's apartment,  Colored lights play on the windows.  Shadows pass.  Finally the front door opens.  There's Veronica Lake, all sparkles and spangles, kissing another distinguished gentleman goodnight.  Bud watches the man into a waiting limo.  As it pulls away...

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: Now Lynn just looks tired.  As she puts away Scotch bottles and picks up empty glasses, there's a KNOCK on the door.  Lynn sighs, become sultry Veronica Lake before our eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (opening door) Did you forget some --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud stands there, filling up the door frame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wondered when you might ring the bell again, Officer White.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Bud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud looks at Lynn a moment, then down at his own feet. Embarrassed.  She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should see yourself.  You look like you're ten years old.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud looks back up.  Lynn's smile fades as she studies his face.  She's not going to ask questions.  Lynn looks at him a moment more, then runs a hand through the blonde hair covering one eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you'd called first, I wouldn't look this ridiculous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lynn comes to Bud naked, her hair brushed back.  Bud goes slow, gently, takes time with his kisses:  like she was a lonely woman he wanted to love to death. Lynn plays off his timing:  her kisses back, her touches. Finally, Bud forces himself to stop.  He pulls back so he can see her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're wondering if Patchett told me to be receptive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud doesn't answer, but yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't matter.  I like you, Bud.  I really do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She kisses him.  Softly, drawing it out.  Not a job.  She wants to make love to him.  And as Bud stops thinking...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack sits in his car waiting.  He checks his watch... 1:30.  Well past midnight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Sid.  Where are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack decides.  MOVE WITH him as he gets out and crosses the street.  The apartment is dark, the front door a few inches ajar.  Suspicious, Jack listens.  Dead quiet.  He enters...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one here it seems.  Till Jack nearly trips over a body.  Matt Reynolds.  Soaked in blood.  Throat slit. Jack looks down in horror as Reynolds seems to stare back up at him.  Jack stumbles out the door.  We hear his CAR DOOR SLAM shut, the SCREECH of RUBBER down the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack pounds on Sid's door till lights switch on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Vincennes!  Open up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hudgeons opens the door.  He's in his pajamas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie!  You got some good scoop for the Sidster?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sid, cut the crap.  I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me some Narco skinny.  I want to put out an all hop-head issue. Shvartze jazz musicians and movie stars.  Maybe tie it into the Rosenbergs.  You like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack grabs him, jerks him into the door frame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (confused) What's wrong, Trash?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened with the kid and Loew?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't get my message?  It got called off.  The kid chickened out at the last minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's dead.  I was just there. Somebody slit his throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus.  Jack, that's a story. 'Swish Actor Gets The Gay Blade.' Let me get my camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hudgeons starts away, but Jack grabs him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loew didn't go with him.  You're sure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I put Reynolds in the cab myself. The night cost me a hundred scoots and I got bupkis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack lets go of him, starts to ramble off into the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jackie!  Big V!  Let me get my camera!  Where are you going?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BARTENDER walks down the bar to where Jack arrives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'll it be, Jack?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pulls out wallet) A bottle of Scotch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the Bartender turns for one, the only bill Jack finds is the President Grant fifty.  The things he's done for fifty bucks... As he looks up with despair at his reflection in the bar mirror, the Bartneder sets down a bottle and shot glass.  He plucks the fifty from Jack's hand. Jack grabs the bottle and starts out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey!  Your change!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spent, Bud and Lynn lie in bed.  SHe traces a finger over his bicep as he muses on the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who was that guy who was here earlier?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lynn's tracing finger stops on Bud's shoulder -- a small white scar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't matter.  All they get is Veronica Lake.  You got the real Lynn Margaret Bracken... (re: scar) Where'd this come from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I was ten, my old man threw a bottle at my mother.  I guess I got in the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you saved her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  But not for long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud looks away.  Lynn sees he doesn't want to talk about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you like being a cop, Bud?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I used to.  What I do now is strong-arm.  Sitting duck stuff... No, I don't like it.  If I could work Homicide like a real detective...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lynn listens sympathetically.  Bud's opening up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's something wrong with the Nite Owl.  That prick Exley shot the wrong guys.  But they made him a hero and whoever killed my partner is still out there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frustrated, Bud pokes at his own chest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In here I know it.  But I can't prove it.  I'm not a detective. I'm not smart enough.  I'm just the guy they bring in to scare the other guy shitless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud looks away, embarrassed to have shown so much of himself.  Lynn reaches over, turns his face back to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You found Patchett.  You found me. You're smart enough.  Be a detective if that's what you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That simple, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lynn nods.  That simple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exley looks up as a CLERK enters holding two files.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got the rap sheets on the black guys, sir.  Coates and Jones got charges a mile long.  But except for some kid stuff, Fontaine's clean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More or less.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Until he gunned down six people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exley stands in the trees as a PARK RANGER approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I asked my men, Lieutenant.  No one remembers any colored guys firing shotguns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then who phoned in the report?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray Pinker looks up from his microscope as Bud enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud White, what brings you down to the basement?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got a few Nite Owl questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know if you read the papers, but that case is closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm tying up loose ends.  Padding my report.  You know how it goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want to know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything off.  Anything that didn't make sense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean beside the fact that thirty-five out of forty-five rounds were gratuitous?  I can't think of anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pinker is ticked as Bud steps over to where a group of Nite Owl crime scene photos are posted on the wall.  Bud pauses at a photo which shows the floor around the table. We see a high heel shoe, blood smears across the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whose shoe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susan Lefferts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing) If she was sitting here, then it's facing the wrong way.  What are these smears in the blood?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It looks like she was flailing, trying to get away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But she's moving away from the door. (thinks; points) Who was sitting at this table?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dick Stensland. (a beat) Had to be dumb panic.  If she knew him she would've been sitting with him... Right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud wonders, maybe a puzzle piece just fell into place. Pinker remembers something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, there is one thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pinker rummages a shelf for a glass jar which he hands Bud.  Inside are two wax-saturated cotton balls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cotton balls.  I found them just inside the meat locker door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ear plugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly.  At least one of those animals had the brains to protect his ears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't exactly play like dumb panic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's like they knew they were going to kill everyone before they went in...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, so...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud just stares at the picture of Susan Lefferts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A shingle shack dump.  Bud walks the front steps, RINGS the BELL.  Hilda Lefferts answers.  She doesn't look so good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Lefferts, I'm Officer White with the L.A.P.D.  I'd like to ask a couple of questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let my daughter rest in peace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five minutes.  That's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pictures of Susan smile down from four walls.  Vamp poses on a nightclub floor.  Mrs. Lefferts is all twitchy and nervous, her eyes darting to a closed door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me about the boyfriend she had.  The one you mentioned at the morgue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First I want to go on record as saying that my Susie was a virgin when she died.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ma'am, I'm sure she was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Lefferts talks directly to a photo of her daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susie, I told you I didn't approve of that boyfriend.  He was too old for you.  You let him come into this house and be fresh to me.  I went out one day and old Mrs. Jensen next door saw Susan's boyfriend and another man and thought she heard a ruckus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was that boyfriend's name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were never properly introduced. Susan and I were fighting that day.  She called him by a nickname.  Muns or Lunts or something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stens?  Was it Stens?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe.  I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at a picture for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud hands her a snapshot of Stensland taken in Tijuana. Out of uniform.  She recognizes him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's him.  That's him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said a neighbor heard a ruckus.  Was it outside, inside?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Lefferts' eyes go crazy, darting to a closed door. Rolled towels are crammed against the bottom of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.  You'll have to leave now, Officer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud starts for the closed door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's through here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!  Please leave!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud kicks away the towels, opens the door, steps into...

dialogues.speaker: DEN
dialogues.text: Innocuous except for the smell.  It hits Bud right off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't mind the smell.  I think a rat died behind the wall... My Susie was a good girl!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy.  Tell me about the ruckus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I came home that night and there was blood on the floor.  Susan said Stams -- Stens had cut himself.  They were acting nervous.  And that Stens kept going under the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Mrs. Lefferts goes shrill, Bud beelines out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holding a flashlight, Bud crawls under the house, into...

dialogues.speaker: CRAWLSPACE
dialogues.text: Bud elbow-crawls over the dirt, between wooden pilings. There's a long burlap sack ahead.  It smells bad.  Bud rips burlap.  A rat's nest explodes.  Bud sweeps a forearm at them.  As they clear, he sees a gristle-caked human skull staring back, a .38 hole in the forehead. Undaunted, Bud tears the burlap back further.  He pats the corpse's pockets, comes up with a wallet.  Bud checks the ID.  "Turner Meeks."  Bus knows him by that name and another.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buzz Meeks... Holy shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud crawls out, blinking sunlight and gulping fresh air. Mrs. Lefferts is there.  She's scared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was it... a rat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  A great big one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud opens Meeks' wallet, pulls out a couple hundred bucks and gives them to Mrs. Lefferts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here.  Compliments of the Los Angeles Police Department.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray Pinker looks up from an autopsy as Exley enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, just in time for our stomach of the week.  Frankfurters with sauerkraut, French fries, Coca-Cola, alcohol and sperm. Jesus, what a last supper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The stiff is Matt Reynolds!  Pinker continues working away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Nite Owl.  Anything bothering you about the case?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  The fact that you guys won't let it get filed away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud White grilled me on it this morning.  You know, he's not as dumb as I thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Exley's head swims...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Lefferts waters the grass, watches as a car pulls up.  Exley gets up, starts toward her.  She drops the hose and runs for the front door  Exley cuts her off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let my Susie rest in peace!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Lefferts, I just want to ask a few questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That other policeman already checked under the house and found not a thing amiss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Officer White?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sweet man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thinking out loud) Under the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All he found were rodents.  No signs of foul play.  So there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exley spots the entrance to the crawlspace.  He hurries over, enters nearly flat on his belly.  Mrs. Lefferts calls in after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My daughter was a virgin!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't doubt it -- Oh, God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack sits unshaven and hung-over, the dregs of the Scotch bottle on the desk.  He considers a framed "Badge of Honor" photo:  Jack and Brett Chase, before a banner "To Protect and Serve."  Jack punches a fist through it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exley walks alonside as a body bag is wheeled into the lab atop a gurney.  Pinker steps over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need an I.D. ASAP.  You talk only to me on this one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sitting in disgust, Jack spots something amidst all the clutter -- the Great Jerk-Off Books of 1962.  He flips one over, looks at the Fleur-de-Lis stamp.  Jack remembers something Matt Reynolds told him.  He dials the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  Sergeant Jack Vincennes requesting.  I need the home address on a Pierce Patchett.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please hold, Sergeant...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Jack waits, Exley appears in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need to speak to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me a minute, will ya?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exley clicks off the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damnit... What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to follow Bud White.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even I'm not that crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not a request.  I need to know what White knows.  Follow him or I'll have you pulled off 'Badge of Honor.'  Permanently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yesterday that might've meant something.  Pull me off.  You'd be doing me a big favor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yesterday yes, today no.  What happened last night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Transfer me, suspend me.  Just leave me alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You make a mistake?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  My whole life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack stands, heads out.  Exley follows; he needs help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, I think I made a mistake, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't a priest, Lieutenant.  I can't hear your confession.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you make the three Negroes for the Nite Owl killings?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a simple question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should be the last person who wants to dig any deeper into the Nite Owl, Lieutenant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exley watches as Jack continues down a hall.  Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rollo Tomasi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack stops, looks back at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there more to that, or do I have to guess?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rollo was a purse snatcher.  My father ran into him off duty.  He shot my father six times and got away clean.  No one even knew who he was.  I made the name up to give him some personality.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what's the point?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rollo's the reason I became a cop. I wanted to catch the guys who thought they could get away with it.  It was supposed to be about truth and justice and Rollo.  But somewhere along the way I forgot all that... How about you, Jack? Why'd you become a cop?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack looks like he might cry, but smiles instead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't remember...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both men are quiet a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm trying to figure what angle you're playing this time, but I sure as hell can't see one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've given up angles for awhile. I just want to solve this thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Nite Owl was solved, Lieutenant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to do it right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So does Jack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, college boy, I'll help you. But I want half the collar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A third.  I don't think we can make a case without Bud White.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Packard pulls up out front.  Bud gets out, heads inside.  Another car pulls up across the street.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Watching Bud.  Jack gets out, starts across the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the bar, Johnny Stompanato looks over as Bud joins him.  Stompanato isn't happy about it, but he smiles anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wendell White, how's tricks, paesano?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't your paesano, you wop cocksucker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nervous, Johnny taps his pinkie ring on a bottle of beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want, officer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You remember an ex-cop named Buzz Meeks?  He works for a guy named Patchett.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnny taps his ring harder.  The bottle almost tips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Should I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His file listed you as a known associate.  Now spill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah.  That was a long time ago.  Before your day.  The last few years he's been muscle for hire.  But I heard he's disappeared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More's gonna cost you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud's hand flashes out, grabs Stompanato by the crotch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How 'bout I give you your balls back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in considerable pain) Before Meeks disappeared he was popping off about trying to move eighteen pounds of heroin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bullshit.  Where would a two-bit ex-cop get 18 pounds of heroin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deuce Perkins.  Mickey C's narcotics lieutenant.  The night he got clipped, eighteen pounds of Mickey's heroin went missing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud loosens his grip.  Stompanato gasps for air.

dialogues.speaker: DOOR
dialogues.text: Jack peels in, catches a glimpse of Bud and Stompanato. Too far away too hear anything, Jack quickly ducks out.

dialogues.speaker: BAR
dialogues.text: Stompanato's recovering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meeks is probably in Rio or someplace like that by now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's under a tract house in San Berdoo.  And he don't smell too good.  What happened to the heroin, Johnny?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.  I swear it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud starts to raise a hand.  Stompanato cringes, but Bud just slaps a twenty down on the bar and goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack's on the phone to Exley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's in the Brown Derby with Johnny Stompanato. (sees Bud exit) Check that.  I gotta go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack pulls up, sees Bud knock on the front door.  It opens and Bud steps in.  Jack doesn't see who opens it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LEAVES RUSTLE.  There's movement in the underbrush.  Jack appears, followed by Exley.  Jack pulls a gun as they near a window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud White.  He sees us and we're dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They press up to the glass for a partial view.  Bud White sits on a footstool massaging a pair of women's feet. Jack and Exley exchange a long, curious look.  This isn't the Bud White they're used to.  A pair of woman's hands take Bud, the arms covered in glitter and satin. The woman, Lynn Bracken, leans forward to kiss her policeman.  It may have been a long day, but she's every inch Veronica Lake.  Only the hair's not over her eye. They stand, kiss again.  Lynn's gown spills down around her ankles.  Bud scoops Lynn into his arms and the two of them disappear into a bedroom.  A long beat before...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus... Maybe White's not so dumb after all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rita Hayworth at the morgue and now Veronica Lake with White. What the hell's going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Movie star hookers.  Whatever you desire... It's Fleur-fr-Lis again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's Fleur-de-Lis?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: High line whores.  With plastic surgery to look like movie stars. And who knows what else?  It's run by this guy Pierce Patchett.  You want to talk to him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  But first I want to brace Stompanato.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exley and Jack enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Check the bar.  I got the restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: RESTAURANT
dialogues.text: Exley scans.  There's Stompanato with a girl who looks amazingly like "LANA TURNER." Engrossed, Stomapanato doesn't look up till Exley's nearl on top of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, you want an autograph, write to M-G-M.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since when do two-bit hoods and hookers give out autographs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Stompanato stands, Exley flashes his badge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: L.A.P.D.  Sit down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who in the hell do you think you are?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take a walk, honey, before I haul your ass downtown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who in the hell do you think are?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are making a large mistake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Jack arrives, Lana tosses a drink in Exley's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get away from our table!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grabs her wrist) Shut up.  Being cut to look like Lana Turner doesn't mean you are Lana Turner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack pulls him aside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is Lana Turner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is Lana Turner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rolling.  The sky glows ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How was I supposed to know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A moment before Jack begins to laugh.  Exley joins him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exley's Plymouth is parked on the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a silk robe, the unflappable Pierce Patchett smiles at Exley.  Jack stands alongside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe the Nite Owl's your area of expertise, Mr. Exley.  I saw you on television getting your medal. (turns to Jack) And you're that other celebrity Hollywood policeman, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.  Exley and Jack don't look like they appreciate being joked with.  Patchett finally sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell you what I told Officer White when he asked me about Susan's death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a look to Jack) Bud White's been here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the last time.  I may suborn women into illicit activities, but they're handsomely compensated, I treat them well and make sure the men they deal with show them every due respect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is the Veronica Lake look-alike one of your whores?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A vulgar term, but yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's her name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lynn Bracken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why's she seeing Bud White?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do men and women usually see each other?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything else you want to add before I talk to her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not good enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (unfazed) Then try talking to my lawyer. Good evening, gentlemen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exley and Jack head for the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guy's as cool as they come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A call CRACKLES in over Exley's RADIO.  Exley picks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Exley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray Pinker wants to talk to you, Lieutenant.  Says he has your I.D.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell him Sergeant Vincennes is coming in to talk to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you going to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to Lynn Bracken's.  I'll meet you at the Dining Car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great.  You get the girl, I get the coroner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watching Exley and Vincennes from the window, Patchett picks up the phone, dials.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over phone) Hush-Hush.  Off the record and on the Q.T.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KNOCKING on the door.  Lynn answers to reveal Exley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Bracken, I'm Lieutenant Exley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know who you are.  You're the policeman Bud told me about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?  What did White say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said you were smart.  He also said you were competing with your dead father.  How did he put it? Trying to measure up to a ghost.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exley lets it pass.  As he enters...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's concentrate on my smarts. Pierce Patchett made you, didn't he?  He taught you how to dress and talk and think and I am very impressed with the results.  But I need some answers and if I don't get them, I'm going to take you and Patchett down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can take care of himself and I'm not afraid of you.  And you forgot one thing, Lieutenant. Pierce also taught me how to fuck... Can I get you a drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exley can't help but smile.  Lynn smiles back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scotch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exley watches her as she steps over to fix the drinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm curious about you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hands him his drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because Bud hates you more than he loves me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exley stews.  Lynn watches him over the rim of her glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It galls you that I know so much about you.  You don't have information to compete.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't underestimate me, Miss Bracken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The way you've underestimated Bud White?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exley's had it.  A menacing step forward.  Lynn's smile becomes a laugh.  Lost to himself, Exley leans in and kisses her.  Lynn pulls back, then kisses back.  In a beat, they're rolling to the floor, shedding clothes. As they trash the furniture, Lynn looks over his shoulder at her own reflection in a closet door mirror.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE CLOSET
dialogues.text: Two-way glass.  Sid Hudgeons is in here SNAPPING pictures.  As Lynn and Exley continue with their frantic lovemaking...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray Pinker rubs his tired eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God bless dental records.  Stiff used to be a cop.  Turner Meeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buzz Meeks?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You knew him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of him.  He was around when I first joined the force.  A bad egg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pinker could care less.  As Jack's wheels turn...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack searches dusty filing cabinets with dates like 1939 and 1940.  Reading one headed "Meeks," Jack lets out a low whistle.  He's found something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack waits at the bar, watches the door anxiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Exley.  Where are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spent, Exley and Lynn sit, half-dressed, on the floor. They're quiet.  Then, through a smile:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How was I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, the best I ever had. Absolutely the best.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs) You sound like you mean it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The silver screen's loss is your gain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about White?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to know what Bud's like in bed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She actually embarrasses him with that one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to know why you see him. Is it a Patchett payoff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see Bud because I want to.  I see Bud because he can't hide the warmth he has inside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take your word for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see Bud because he makes me feel like Lynn Bracken and not some Veronica Lake look-alike who fucks for money.  I see him because he doesn't know how to disguise who he is.  There's more if you want to hear it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exley shakes his head.  He's heard enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does all that make it harder for you to hate him or easier?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't hate White.  I really don't.  It's just, in my business, it's the wild cars you have to watch out for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't like that you don't know how to play him.  He doesn't follow the same rules of politics you do.  That makes him dangerous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You cut to the heart of things, don't you?  What about Lynn Bracken?  She going to be a hooker all her life?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I came out here with a dream. That's gone, but I settled for reality.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some reality.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  This is the means to the reality.  But I'm not going to tell you what it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because you'll use it against me. Won't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exley doesn't answer, but the answer is yes.  Lynn smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're tougher than Bud thinks you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) You're the first person to ever call me tough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like recognizes like.  I'm pretty tough, myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You, me and White, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, Bud's only tough on the outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Exley kisses her...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exasperated that he's still stuck in here, Sid Hudgeons checks his watch, shakes his head in disgust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack knocks at a darkened house.  The porch lights come on.  The door opens to reveal Dudley Smith in his bathrobe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John Vincennes.  It's three A.M., lad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two minutes, Dudley.  It's important.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucky for you that my wife and four fair daughters are at the beach in Santa Barbara.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack sits at the table while Dudley makes coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
